bibl.title: Ben cao gang mu dictionary Vol1

sense.def: a) of an item having entered the scrotum, with pain, sometimes ascending, sometimes descending. Jin gui yao lue 金匱要略 Mj: 陰狐疝氣者，偏有小大，時時上下，蜘蛛 散主之 , “In the case of yin-fox-type elevation-illness qi , with one side being small and the other being enlarged, and an alternating movement up- and downward, the powder with zhi zhu will control this”.

b) Of a condition affecting the scrotum or a testicle. Wai tai mi yao 外台秘要 10: 療腎虛疝氣，腰膝冷疼，陰囊腫癢，狐陰 丸方 , “To cure kidney depletion and elevation-illness qi , swelling and itching of the scrotum, [use] the recipe for pills [to cure] ‘fox in the yin ’”.

c) Identical with shan 疝 , elevation-illness. Shen nong ben cao jing 神農本草經 Substance Entry wu jia pi 五加皮：主心腹疝氣，腹 痛 , “It controls the heart and abdomen with elevation-illness qi , and abdominal pain”. In the Ben cao gang mu 本草綱目 the first two meanings dominate. The image of a “fox” implies an item moving erratically inside the body – in this case in the scrotum. Ru men shi qin 儒門事親 explains: “The item [in the scrotum] is shaped like a tile. When [the patient] lies down to sleep, it enters the lower abdomen. When he walks and stands it leaves the lower abdomen and enters the scrotum. A fox leaves its den in the morning to urinate. It enters its den at night and will not urinate there. This elevation-illness comes out and withdraws, moves upward and downward, just like a fox”.
